title: Jesus' Journey to Jerusalem
shortSummary: Luke 19 records Jesus' encounter with Zacchaeus, illustrating salvation and repentance, followed by the parable of the ten pounds teaching faithful stewardship. The chapter culminates with Jesus' triumphal entry into Jerusalem, His lament over the city, and His cleansing of the temple, highlighting His authority and the coming judgment.
timeline: c. AD 30 - Final journey of Jesus to Jerusalem

keyCharacters.name: Jesus
keyCharacters.description: The Son of Man who seeks and saves the lost, teaches in parables, and asserts His messianic authority in Jerusalem.

keyCharacters.name: Zacchaeus
keyCharacters.description: A chief tax collector in Jericho who repents and receives salvation after encountering Jesus.

keyCharacters.name: The Nobleman
keyCharacters.description: The central figure in Jesus' parable representing Christ, who entrusts servants with resources to steward until His return.

keyCharacters.name: The Pharisees
keyCharacters.description: Religious leaders who challenge Jesus and His disciples, particularly during the triumphal entry.

definitions.definition: Tax collectors who were often despised by Jews for collaborating with Roman authorities and collecting taxes.
A type of fig tree common in the region, often low and spreading, which Zacchaeus climbed to see Jesus.
A unit of currency used in Jesus' parable, representing entrusted resources or responsibilities.
A phrase Jesus used to condemn the corruption and commercial exploitation occurring in the temple courts.

outline.heading: Jesus and Zacchaeus in Jericho
outline.description: Jesus meets Zacchaeus, a wealthy tax collector who seeks Him despite obstacles. Zacchaeus repents, promising restitution, and Jesus declares salvation has come to his house, emphasizing His mission to seek the lost.

outline.heading: Parable of the Ten Pounds
outline.description: Jesus tells a parable about a nobleman who entrusts servants with money before receiving a kingdom. The parable teaches faithfulness, stewardship, and the consequences of rejecting Christ's reign.

outline.heading: Triumphal Entry into Jerusalem
outline.description: Jesus approaches Jerusalem riding on a colt, fulfilling prophecy. The crowd praises Him as King, while Pharisees rebuke the disciples, and Jesus affirms the inevitability of His praise.

outline.heading: Jesus' Lament Over Jerusalem
outline.description: Jesus weeps over Jerusalem, foretelling its coming destruction because of its failure to recognize the time of God's visitation.

outline.heading: Cleansing of the Temple and Teaching
outline.description: Jesus drives out those buying and selling in the temple, declaring it a house of prayer corrupted into a den of thieves. He teaches daily, despite opposition from religious leaders seeking to kill Him.

application: Seek Jesus earnestly like Zacchaeus, overcoming obstacles to know Him personally and respond in repentance.
Be faithful stewards of the resources and responsibilities God has entrusted to you, working diligently until Christ returns.
Praise Jesus openly as King, recognizing His authority even when opposed by others.
Heed Jesus' warnings and embrace His visitation to avoid spiritual ruin and experience peace.

keyVerses.text: For the Son of man is come to seek and to save that which was lost.
keyVerses.significance: This verse summarizes Jesus' mission and purpose, emphasizing His role as Savior of sinners.

keyVerses.text: And Jesus said unto him, This day is salvation come to this house, forsomuch as he also is a son of Abraham.
keyVerses.significance: Highlights the immediate effect of repentance and faith, affirming Zacchaeus' inclusion in God's covenant people.

keyVerses.text: But those mine enemies, which would not that I should reign over them, bring hither, and slay them before me.
keyVerses.significance: A solemn warning about the judgment awaiting those who reject Christ's sovereign rule.

keyVerses.text: Saying unto them, It is written, My house is the house of prayer: but ye have made it a den of thieves.
keyVerses.significance: Jesus' rebuke of temple corruption underscores the need for holiness and reverence in worship.
